comments.author: DarwinJS
comments.body: There is an official docker image (https://hub.docker.com/r/linuxmintd/mint19-amd64/), but do you bother with doing tests only for install scripts?

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: I ran the install-ps CI here and set it to automatically run in the future:  https://powershell.visualstudio.com/PowerShell/_build/results?buildId=7894

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
@DarwinJS 	It's a lot easier to be confident that it works with a CI system in place.

Thanks for keeping these up to date.

comments.author: DarwinJS
comments.body: LinuxMint is worth it - finally a distro that does not annoy the daylights out of all my windows keyboard shortcut reflexes :)

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: I like LinuxMint too, but I found macOS has the apps I need to run it full time.

comments.author: DarwinJS
comments.body: Yes - I don't use it as a primary - but for testing bash and powershell core since the rest of my team runs macs.  Although I am doing more of that with Docker as well.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: I started using https://github.com/CanonicalLtd/multipass for a lot of my testing of Linux from macOS.  This is partly because I'm testing snap packages which don't really work in docker.

title: support for linuxmint in installpsh-debian.sh
